Title.En: Exploring the diversity of alcoholic beverages in the world SS24_25

Description.En:
This micromodule presents theoretical knowledge and supports the development of practical skills in the field of alcohol production, with particular emphasis on alcoholic beverages and their global socio-economical relevance, influence of the raw materials and production technology on beer flavour, sensory evaluation techniques in beer flavour assessment, the influence of grape varieties, yeast type, and maturation techniques on wine diversity, exploring wine regions, finding wine flaws.

It contains sections specifically devoted to the topic of: beer production and styles; white wine, red wine, and orange wine production technology, as well as vodka, tequila, and whisky technologies.

NoteLiteral.En: Identify diverse types of alcoholic beverages accorting to their geographical origin and production method.
Describe production methods used in beer, wine and spirit making.

PrefLabel.En: minimise environmental impact on the surrounding area

NoteLiteral.En: Briefly explain the science of the conversion of raw materials into final alcoholic products.
List and explain sensory evaluation techniques used in beer, wine and spirit flavour assessment.

Title.En: Exploring the diversity of alcoholic beverages in the world SS24_25
Exploring the diversity of alcoholic beverages in the world SS24_25

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
The Learning outcomes in this course are assessed through short online multiple-choice tests and cases with immediate feedback. Each case is followed by a few questions. Answers to these questions are provided and self-checked by the student.

The course consists of 10 modules, created by a team of TUL Biotechnology and Food Science Faculty Members. Each module contains video(s) and PPT(s) with the topic information. The video content is then recycled in the tests and case-study activities. As this is an online course, students can access the course any time during the whole summer semester of 2024/25 and have the possibility to complete it at their own pace.

The estimated overall time spent in this course is 45: 10 hours of lectures, 15 hours of assignments, and 20 hours of  self-study. The learning environment is Lodz University of Technology Moodle Platform.
How not to get lost in the infinite diversity of alcoholic beverages in the world.

Are you into fermentation, distillation, alcohol sensory evaluation techniques, various technologies of alcohol production and other related issues? This micromodule will allow you to explore the profound diversity of alcoholic beverages across various geographical locations. It is divided into three main sections: 1) beer styles, 2) wine types, 3) spirits and other liquors – each focusing on the unique characteristics and flavour profiles of these three classes. A basic understanding of the role of raw materials and the different production processes will be explained. Both the traditional and the modern methods of production will be confronted. Particular attention will be drawn to the unique sensory attributes of the beverages for a given type/style and the geographical region of its origin.

This is an online course. Submission is possible until May 31, 2025. All applicants are required to comply with Universal ECIU University Admission Criteria. All applicants must by above 18 years old. It is required to submit a one-page-CV and a short note explaining why a candidate decides to take this course.  
You can add this learning opportunity (micro-module) to your Flexible Learning Pathway (FLP). Flexible learning pathway (FLP) – personalised learning experience of different lengths and depths depending on what skills and competences the learner wants to acquire with the possibility of changing learning direction along the way. This micro-module can be included as part of FLP and can help develop domain, transversal or preparatory competencies.
